characters: DIFFERENT PEOPLE PASSING THEM AND SHAKIN
HAS A LEVER ATTACHED THAT PUSHES TWO METAL RODS DOWN THAT
AHEAD BETWEEN THE CAR IN FRONT OF HER AND THE CAR THAT
DIFFERENT PEOPLE PASSING JOY AND RONNIE

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (playful) Ooh, I don’t know where my husband is. I’ve already lost him and we've only been married twenty minutes! Joy's BEST FRIEND RONNIE, 30, a SASSY, ITALIAN BETTE MIDL approaches. She holds a plate and eats while she follows Joy.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Tony’s eating. I made you a plate. It’s at the table. Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I’m coming. (to guests) How’s the ziti though, guys? Rosati’s did everything. Is it okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joy. Come on. Joy heads off, Ronnie behind her. She runs into an older FEMALE RELATIVE.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER WOMAN GUEST
dialogues.text: Joy, congratulations! I just had my uterus out. I’m not even supposed to be here but I don’t listen to doctors.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh--Auntie Olga! I’m so grateful that you came. Go sit. Did you get a plate? I’m gonna make you a plate.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Joy. Joy and Ronnie move through crowd, passing JOY’S MOTHER, TOOTS, 60-ish, who stands by herself. As she talks to her mother, Joy squats down, uses the NAPKIN in her hand to h a little girl get a stain out of her dress.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Here you go, Marie. Mom, you're still standing here? Why don’t you sit?

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: Did you notice your father spray- painted his bald spot? Who does he think he’s fooling? He’s not fooling her. They both glance over to a table where Joy’s father RUDY like a KING with his arm around a ROBUST woman in an ill- fitting MARILYN MONROE DRESS. His hair looks shiny.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Mom, let it go. Just for today. Toots walks off, muttering to herself.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: He’s glossy. He looks like a children’s toy. This is Joy--everything to everyone.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Club soda. See. All gone.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: Thank you! The little girl runs off. Joy stands up next to Ronnie. brushes her dress off, takes it all in.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Wow. Best day of my life. It happened. Ronnie notices a GROUP OF MEN that has congregated in one spot. They watch a WOMAN WITH HUGE BREASTS walk by. They and cat call to the woman, amused by themselves. The woma knows they are watching her, she keeps walking, insecure.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Look at these animals. You think they’ve never seen a set of boobs in their life. We’re married to these people. Good luck, we just got shot down the hatch. That’s it. End of story. We’re in it. Suddenly a VOICE comes over the loud speaker.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S)
dialogues.text: This song is dedicated to my bride. Joy and Ronnie look to the stage. Joy’s husband, TONY MANGANO, has the microphone. He is 1980’s GORGEOUS. Thick curly brown hair, dimples. There is something about this He meets eyes with Joy.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Come on, they’re not all bad.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Joy, even the best dog is two meals away from bein’ a wolf.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: This is a song that says it better than I could. From the lyrical genius. Baby, here’s a little Tom Jones for ya. The lights GO OUT. A DISCO BALL turns on and paints the r with lights. A SPOTLIGHT comes up on Tony, who now has hi jacket off, his sleeves rolled up, and his back to the cr in a DRAMATIC pose. Las Vegas has just shown up to the pa The band begins playing. The crowd goes WILD. Tony TURNS AROUND. His SHIRT is UNBUTTONED down to his be button and his HAIRY CHEST on display. He is SERIOUS. He plays to the crowd. This isn’t the first time he’s done this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With these hands...I will cling to you...I'm yours forever and a day... He JUMPS OFF THE STAGE onto the DANCE FLOOR, lands and sp effortlessly. Everyone cheers. He starts making his way o to Joy.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Uh-oh, he’s comin' this way. He’s comin’ over.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: With these hands, I will bring to you, a tender love as warm as May... He turns his backside to the crowd and circles his hips. Women cheer. Ronnie puts her hand up to shield them from view. Joy laughs, blushing. Tony signals the LARGE-BREAST WOMAN that the group of men was ogling.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who wants to dance? Come here, sweetheart. The woman shyly comes toward him. He twirls her around an dips her with one hand. Joy rolls her eyes and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With this heart, I will sing to you, long after stars have lost their glow... (the woman keeps looking at another woman in the crowd) Who’s that? Is that your sister? (The woman nods) I've never danced with two sisters before! Tony pulls the sister up and dances with them both, one o each arm.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And with these hands I will provide for you... He spins them both out and back in. They all sway back an forth, sensually. The woman next to Joy is uncomfortable. fakes being mad, pointing her finger at him playfully.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Should there be a stormy sea I'll turn the tide for you... They pivot and we see that one of the women’s hands has its way to Tony’s ass. Just as Joy becomes slightly visib uncomfortable, Tony spins the women back into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ho! It’s my wedding day! Where’s my wife? He searches the room. Locating Joy, he turns ALL of his attention on her.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There she is. Come here baby. Isn't she beautiful, everyone? Joy blushes, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's more beautiful than Crystal Gayle. The crowd ahhs. This wins Joy over. He pulls her up and dances closely with her as he BELTS IT OUT in her face--

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: NOOOO, I'll never. No, I'll never LET YOU GO!!!... They kiss. There is a dance break in the song. They dance

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, whattaya think? You still wanna be Mrs. Tony Mangano. You haven't changed your mind yet?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I guess I will under one condition.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: You have to sing that song to me every day for the rest of my life.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: You got it, baby! Tony gets infused with energy.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oooohooohhhh!!! And I'll never, NO I'll never... He spins Joy and continues singing...  The song continues over card: 7 YEARS LATER. INT. JOY AND TONY'S HOUSE. MORNING. Very humble, BLUE COLLAR SUBURBAN home. Some DEAD BUSHES the front. A DECORATIVE GRAPEVINE WREATH on the front doo warms the look of the place.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “ Long after stars, have lost their glow...!" Tony's voice still belting, only now it’s from the shower Joy is in the kitchen preparing breakfast for their THREE KIDS--CHRISTIE 7, BOBBY, 6 AND JACKIE 4. They are engaged LIVELY morning chatter.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: AA-AA-AA-AA-AAND, with these hands, I will provide for you!"

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Who wants toast?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE/JACKIE
dialogues.text: I do/Me! Joy puts toast in the toaster and pushes the lever down.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Not me! I hate toast.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Let’s not say ‘hate’. Toast is just cooked bread. How can you not like cooked bread?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE
dialogues.text: I love cooked bread. I love toast.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I’m not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Three bites. Come on, Bobby. You need your energy for school. Suddenly smoke starts pouring out of the toaster.

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE/JACKIE
dialogues.text: What happened mommy? Joy starts to fan the smoke, trying to stay cheery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staying cheery) This toaster likes to burn everything all of a sudden. It’s okay. What is goin’ on with this thing? Joy unplugs the toaster. She examines it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE
dialogues.text: Is it on fire?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: No, no, no. She studies the inside of the toaster. TONY enters in his towel. He’s all man.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Sompn’ on fire?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (taking care of business) No, no, we’re not on fire. Everything's fine. Tony walks through the smoke and opens the fridge. He pul out a piece of STEAK from a TUPPERWARE container. Joy takes FOIL out of a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (taking a bite) Baby, where’s my interview suit?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I got it pressed. It’s in the closet in the plastic. Joy tears off just the right size of foil. She slides the foil in the toaster next to the toast so that the hot rod not overcook the bread.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Daddy's got a big interview today. Gonna get in the potato chip business. If things go well, start thinking about an above ground swimming pool, that’s all I’m sayin'. Joy puts three pieces of toast back in.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Yay!!/Yes!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playful) A pool? They don’t want a pool.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Yes we do!!! Joy watches the toast. Adjusts the foil. Tony looks at he

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Babe what are you doin’? Listen, on the way home I’m gonna pick you up a new toaster.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: We don’t need a new toaster.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Come on. It’s a toaster.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (alarmed but trying to keep it light) We don’t have the money for a new toaster. I can fix it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah you’re gonna spend all day tinkering with it when you could be doin’ other stuff.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: It’s not that big of a deal. Please don’t spend any money. We gotta pay the electric bill.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (plays to the kids) What do we need electricity for? The Flinstones didn’t have electricity. We just need a dinosaur, you know. (gets a mischievous look) You know what I think we need? The kids eyes’ go wide. They know what’s coming.

dialogues.speaker: TONY KIDS
dialogues.text: A tickle’o’saurus! A tickle’o’saurus! Tony lunges at the kids, tickling each one, as they SCREA with joy.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Ahhh! /NO!!/Tickle ME daddy!  Then he comes over to Joy, threatens to tickle her.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What about Wilma? Is Wilma ticklish?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Don’t. Ahhhh!! NO!!!! (laughing) Alright, go get dressed! You’re in a towel! You are in a towel!! Tony goes off down the hallway where only Joy can see him RIPS the towel off while walking.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No I’m not. We see his BARE ASS as he walks into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh my--Get dressed! Joy shakes her head, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE
dialogues.text: What’s he doing?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Your father’s a caveman. Three perfectly toasted pieces of bread pop out of the toaster. INT. JOY AND TONY’S HOUSE. LATER THAT MORNING. Kids are at school. Joy finishes up the breakfast dishes. Joy mops her kitchen floor. The mop pushes around the foo and dirt rather than picking it up. She grabs a paper tow gets down on her hands and knees and cleans the floor wit paper towel. She makes beds. INT. BASEMENT. CONTINUOUS. It looks like an UNDERGROUND FLORIST down here. There are tables set up with BASKETS on them full of different item SILK FLOWERS and LEAVES, sticks, bunches of fake berries, ribbon, pine cones, and pruning shears. Everything is ver neat and organized.  10. We see various shots of Joy grabbing from the different baskets and glueing LEAVES, BERRIES, FLOWERS, MINI-PINE CONES. She takes a RIBBON and ties it at the top, then ho it up to check her work. It is a VERY PRETTY DECORATIVE GRAPEVINE WREATH. She sets it aside and grabs more twigs. EXT. JOY AND TONY’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. Joy loads the boxes into the back of her car. INT. FLOWER SHOP. ROZ, the owner, stands in front of a cooler full of flowe Joy holds a bunch of wreaths. She’s less put together tha Roz.

dialogues.speaker: ROZ
dialogues.text: I don’t need anymore, Joy.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Are you sure? I have this harvest theme one, and this one is very warm looking, and I have a few Hanukkah ones with dreidels.

dialogues.speaker: ROZ
dialogues.text: I still have a few left over from last week.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: That’s okay, I thought I would check. (disappointed, then) How are the kids?

dialogues.speaker: ROZ
dialogues.text: Oh, Joy. I hate saying this. I think Vinny’s got something wrong with his brain. I mean nothin serious. This kid’s a mess. Last week he was lying down looking for someone to run over him cause he thought he would survive. He wants to be on ‘That’s Incredible.’ This kid. Johnny says he’s gonna be a stugatz (idiot). Every night I pray he gets healed of whatever this is.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: He’s ten. You know I told you about my cousin Geoffrey, the smart one? He teaches at MIT now, and when we were kids he pretended he was a dog for two years. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We were on summer vacation and he was crawling around on the beach barking.

dialogues.speaker: ROZ
dialogues.text: (baffled) Really.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I think they just go through these phases. It could be a sign that he’s really smart.

dialogues.speaker: ROZ
dialogues.text: That makes me feel better. The dog thing I couldn’t handle. I would have taken him to the pound. They laugh. Joy goes to leave.

dialogues.speaker: ROZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what? Why don’t you leave me a couple of the Hanukkah ones? INT. JOY AND TONY'S HOUSE. AFTERNOON. Joy enters with Jackie in one hand and an almost full box wreaths on the dining room table.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hello? Tony? No answer. INT. JOY AND TONY’S HOUSE. Evening chaos with kids. Joy is at the stove with MULTIPL POTS going. Buzzer going off, etc. Toots models a NEW FAN DRESS as if she’s standing in a department store, oblivio to the fact that Joy could use a hand.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: It’s an exact replica of the dress Nancy Reagan wore at Frank Sinatra's birthday party. Remember the picture I ripped out of Vogue magazine at Dr. Mozingo’s office? This is it. I mean the replica. Joy. Joy look. Look at my dress. Joy runs to the boiling pot, steals a glance at Toots.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s nice mom. Christie, Bobby, Jackie, go wash your hands! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Toots) What’s this dress for?

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: It’s for the next thing. The next thing I have. Joy tries to get the pasta pot to the sink.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Its just you already have so many dresses.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: I’m supposed to have dresses. You think if you walked into Nancy Reagan’s closet it’s just gonna be filled with long shorts? Can you unzip me now? Joy? Joy has her hands full.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Bobby, tv goes off! Let’s go guys!

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: I mean I’ve got the room. You know, it’s just me now. I’m alone.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Mom, it’s been fifteen years.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: Well I still have space in my closets. Do you know how lonely that is? Empty closets in your own house? Joy looks at the CLOCK. 6:40. She’s concerned.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s odd he hasn’t called. That’s not like Tony.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Sometimes it is. Sometimes he gets a drink with Joe and Peter. The kids enter. Christie has overheard and looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE
dialogues.text: Is everything ok?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Everything's fine.  13.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: Well it’s almost 7. Oh God, I hope it’s not the worst.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: He’s fine. (cheerful) Alright, everybody, sit down! INT. HALLWAY. Joy picks toys up off of the floor. She picks up Tony’s t from earlier. Glances at the clock. 10:45. INT. LIVING ROOM. LATER THAT NIGHT. It’s dead quiet. SAME CLOCK READS 1:28. Joy sits on the couch, folding laundry. There is a lot of folded laundry around her. Finally the door opens. Tony enters, quietly, wearing different clothes carrying a small duffel bag. Jo relief quickly turns to disappointment. She stops folding

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Must have been some job interview. Tony is surprised to see her up.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Geez, babe. You scared me. What are you doin’?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Waiting for you. Tony, feeling caught, puts his duffel bag on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I was at the job interview.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Okay. That was 10 am.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It didn't go so well.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (calm) So what then? You don’t call me? You don’t come home til 1:30 in the morning? Where have you been? Pause.  14.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I was at the track.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I had to blow off some steam, okay? The interview was a mess. They told me they already hired someone yesterday but they didn’t want to cancel. So it was a waste of time. Anyway I knew you'd be disappointed. So, I’m sorry baby.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (getting angry) You went to the track? Why wouldn’t you call? I didn’t know where you were. Do you know the thoughts that have been going through my mind? Tony sits next to her and puts his hand on her leg.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I said I was sorry. (turning on the charm) What kind of thoughts were you having? She pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Tony I’m serious.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I’m serious too. What kind of thoughts were you having? Were you thinking about the 600 dollars I won on the number 7 horse in the third race?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: And how I made another 200 on a little horse named ‘Joy’s Toys’? I’m serious, that was the name of the horse. This horse had great legs.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (shakes her head, disappointed) I can’t believe you went to the track.  15.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah but I won. Joy is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Goodnight Tony--

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Wait. Before you go to bed, you should open this bag. Real quick. Tony puts his duffel bag in front of her. Joy is reserved

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go ahead. She sighs, reluctantly opens the bag. She takes out a BRA NEW TOASTER. She shakes her head, only slightly amused.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a four-slice with multiple heat settings. It’s a Cuisinart. He takes out a WAD OF CASH and puts it on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The rest I thought we could take care of the electric bill. I know you were worried about that, and then...whatever else you think. She doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Tony, this isn’t the way--

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Come here. (Joy is not caving) Come here. Tony puts on the charm, walks toward her.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You haven't been to sleep at all? You've been up this whole night? He stands, puts his hands on her hips, kisses her neck.

dialogues.speaker: JOY TONY
dialogues.text: Don’t. I’m sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know how I can make it up to you.  16.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (softening) Well whatever it is it’s not happening tonight.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh yes it is.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (slowly caving) No it’s not.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I think it is.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Well it’s not.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Let me ask you a question. He starts to unbutton her shirt.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How do these buttons come off? Do you just--take’em off? Like one, two... As he unbuttons her shirt, Joy gives in. Shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Tony, you wear me out. EXT. RUDY’S AUTOBODY SHOP. DAY. The wall is COVERED with posters of LARGE BREASTED WOMEN BIKINIS on motorcycles, washing cars, bending over in a g string over the hood of a car, etc. Joy stands with her father RUDY, a small-framed man, whil the KIDS PLAY in the background. Behind them through a window we see TWO GOOMBAHS sit playing cards.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Something’s rubbing up against the tire. Tony wants you to look at it.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah of course. But first there’s someone I want you to meet. (yells outside) Viv!  17. VIV, A mid-60's CHUBBY, JOVIAL WOMAN enters. Her body is of proportion--very round in the middle with skinny bird legs. She’s doing her best to look professional but she’s busting out of the top and the sides. RUDY (CONT’D) Joy, this is Viv. She’s my new office manager and uh...we’re together. She’s a model. Joy's been through this before.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Right. Wow. Hi, it’s nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: VIV
dialogues.text: Hi Joy! I've heard so much about you! I’d love to have you all over sometime and cook for you in my apartment!

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh. Um...yeah. Sure... Behind them, A CAR pulls into the garage. TWO MEN get out One is wearing a very nice suit. This is MATTY THE HORSE. The goombahs playing cards get up and greet the two men. sees Matty.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: You know what, why don’t you two get to know each other. I’11 be right back. Rudy walks hurriedly toward the men.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey Matty! Joy stands alone with Viv, feeling awkward.

dialogues.speaker: VIV
dialogues.text: You have beautiful children.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Joy sees Rudy and Matty walk around the car. Matty talks about the car.

dialogues.speaker: VIV
dialogues.text: My children are all grown up. They don’t talk to me anymore. I don’t know why.  18.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s too bad. I’m sorry. Joy sees Rudy nod agreeably at Matty.

dialogues.speaker: VIV
dialogues.text: They blame me for a lot I guess. Kids love to blame their parents. And maybe something happened with my third husband. Rudy and Matty step back and talk while the goombahs TAKE PLATES off of the car.

dialogues.speaker: VIV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was Australian. He was just culturally different. And I think he might have taken money from them. From their bank accounts.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh, wow. Yeah, maybe that’s what it is. Rudy and Matty shake hands. Joy makes out what Matty says

dialogues.speaker: MATTY
dialogues.text: Okay then. Have a wonderful Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Hey, what’s not to like? Rudy is really trying to impress this guy. He follows beh Matty.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, from time to time I get Yankee tickets, we could go, you know, see a game. Matty pats him politely on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MATTY
dialogues.text: My family’s got a box. The two goombahs begin stripping the car as A BLACK CADIL pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay, so we’ll talk soon. Good seeing you guys. Yep. Great! Matty AND HIS PARTNER get into it and drive off. Rudy com back over, proud.  19.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at this. You two are hitting it off like sisters.

dialogues.speaker: VIV
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Oh Rudy, no! Okay, maybe. I don’t know. Wouldn’t that be fun?!

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Viv, go get me a beer.

dialogues.speaker: VIV
dialogues.text: (loves it) He’s always tellin’ me to do stuff! Joy forces a smile. Viv walks off. Joy looks at Rudy.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Hey. So whattaya think of Viv, huh? She’s pretty hot to trot.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yeah she’s great dad.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: She’s the finest woman I’ve ever known. I wanna bring her over on Sunday for dinner to meet the kids. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Dad, what’s he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: (bragging) Uh, I just did a thing for him so you know, he drops this thing off. It’s business. (then) Let’s take a look at that fender. EXT. HIGHWAY. DAY. Joy drives with groceries in the back, singing to Gregory Abbott “Shake You Down.” She spots what looks like TONY’S CAR going the other way. She does a double take. Was that Tony? She turns around and follows him. He pulls into a MOTEL. Confused, she keeps driving. After a few seconds, pulls over, breaths, turns around, and pulls into the MOT PARKING LOT.  20. EXT. SUPER 8 MOTEL. MOMENTS LATER. A two-story outdoor motel that has 20 rooms with their do facing the parking lot. Joy stands next to the car that s saw. A small box of TOM JONES 8 TRACK TAPES sits on the seat. TONY. Joy looks up at the different motel rooms, tortured over what to do. She finally makes a move into t MOTEL LOBBY. INT. SUPER 8 MOTEL. FRONT DESK. A 50-ish FEMALE DESK CLERK watches a game show.

dialogues.speaker: DESK CLERK
dialogues.text: Philadelphia.

dialogues.speaker: GAME SHOW HOST
dialogues.text: And the answer is...The ocean. She turns off the tv.

dialogues.speaker: DESK CLERK
dialogues.text: Hi, can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hi. I need to find out if you have a Tony Mangano checked in here?

dialogues.speaker: DESK CLERK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I can’t release that information, ma’am. We have a privacy policy.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh. He’s actually my husband. I’m Joy Mangano. Here’s my I.D. Joy anxiously hands the clerk her driver’s license. The c looks at it. The clerk gets a strange look on her face. S KNOWS SOMETHING. The clerk and Joy share a look. JOY (CONT’D) Tony Mangano is the name. Ring any bells? He would have checked in sometime today. That’s his car right there. And I--I just gotta know if he’s here.

dialogues.speaker: DESK CLERK
dialogues.text: (regretfully) I’m sorry ma’‘am. I can’t just release information about a guest. I could lose my job.  21.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Okay. I understand, I’m sorry. I don’t want to break any rules. I’1l just wait. The clerk is surprised as Joy politely takes a seat in on the guest chairs across from the clerk with her hands fol in her lap. Joy fidgets nervously, frequently checking out the window at the motel room doors.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAME. MOMENTS LATER.
dialogues.text: Joy looks out the window. The clerk finishes up a task, t sees Joy still sitting patiently.

dialogues.speaker: DESK CLERK
dialogues.text: Do you know the date today?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Uh...the 19th.

dialogues.speaker: DESK CLERK
dialogues.text: Are you sure it’s not the 28th?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: The 28th? No it’s the 19th. The desk clerk looks at Joy.

dialogues.speaker: DESK CLERK
dialogues.text: Oh I don’t know. I’m pretty sure it’s the 28th. I’m gonna go to the bathroom, but I’m pretty sure today is...number 28. Joy is confused. The desk clerk gets up and as she exits, opens the door of the WOODEN CABINET of room keys behind Joy computes this. After the woman exits, she gets up and takes the number 28 room key from the rack and heads outs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joy self-consciously walks up the stairs, passes the different rooms until she reaches room 28.  22. EXT. MOTEL. CONTINUOUS. Wide shot of Joy walking along the upstairs walkway. She opens the door and goes in. A moment, then... Joy comes out of the room, closes the door, gathers herse walks back down the walkway and down the stairs. Tony com out with a TOWEL around his waist, looks around PANICKED, watching Joy go down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Joy! Joy, wait! A WOMAN walks out of the motel room. She is wrapped in a SHEET. Tony and the woman stand there dumbfounded. Joy hurries into her car and drives off. INT. JOY AND TONY'S HOME. KITCHEN. The three kids are giggling. Joy stares off into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clock reads 10:15 p.m. Joy is focused on making lunches keep from going crazy. She hears TONY’S CAR pull up outsi EXT. JOY AND TONY’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. She stands on the front porch watching him get out of the car. He walks part way up and stops.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Joy--

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: No. No, Tony.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Listen its not-- (Starts over) We were talking--

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (quickly) Are you kidding me? Don’t.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Baby-- TONY walks toward her. Joy backs up, skittish. He registe this.  23.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Joy come on. Its freezing cold out here.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: You're not coming in here. Go wherever you go, but you can’t be here.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (sees a NEIGHBOR come onto their porch) Come on. Let’s go inside and talk about this.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: There’s nothing to talk about. I put the kids to sleep. They are in bed. Not tonight, Tony. You, you go away. Please.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So, what, you’re not going to let me explain?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Ok. Explain.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Number one. You need to calm down. You're flying off the handle here. (reaching) Look I slipped okay. I slipped.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: So this was the first time. He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please have enough respect for me to tell me the truth. He doesn’t say anything. This confirms it for Joy.

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How could you do this? She starts to cry. Tony moves in, starts rubbing her back

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Joy. Joy come on. I love you. You're the mother of my children. You're my family. You're the only woman that will ever truly mean anything to me.  24.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Right. So what are the others? A reflex?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (thinks he’s got her) Come on, let’s go inside. Beat. Joy is determined. Doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: No. You can still see the kids whenever you want--

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What?! What are you talking about?! Joy. So you're gonna break up our family over this?! You are not doing this. (pause) What are you gonna do without me? You thought about that?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I’1ll take my chances.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Well this is just fucking great. What was I supposed to do, huh?! You wanted all this. (waves at their house) I’m out here just trying to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Wow. Okay, so its MY fault. I did this. Joy opens the door, starts heading in the house.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Where am I supposed to go?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (stops, turns) Don’t you have a motel room? Tony looks at Joy. His head DROPS, he turns and walks dow the driveway. INT. JOY AND TONY'S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. Joy closes the door, in shock. She turns around and sees three little pairs of shoes on the floor by the door.  25. INT. RONNIE’S HOUSE. THE NEXT MORNING. Joy sits with Ronnie and her husband Dante, a VERY short, round, Italian man, re: Danny DeVito with a full beard an very full head of hair.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Animal. You're lucky I wasn’t there, Joy, I would have left a crime scene. If Dante ever did anything like that I’d tie him to the roof of the house and set the house on fire.

dialogues.speaker: DANTE
dialogues.text: Hey I’m sittin’ right here.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: You know what? Take those short legs out of here so I can talk to my friend in private. She’s grieving!

dialogues.speaker: DANTE
dialogues.text: Why you mad at me? I didn’t do nothin’.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: You're all animals that’s why! I’m surprised you don’t EAT each other! Dante gets up and walks down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s drivin’ me nuts. You know what he did this morning? He electric- shaved his chest in the bathroom sink and clogged the whole thing up.

dialogues.speaker: DANTE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It was just the hair around my shirt line!

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Just around your shirt? It looked like someone was cuttin' a carpet in there. A curly, black, coarse carpet! I can’t use my sink now, it’s like someone shoved a raccoon down the pipes. I tell you what, it better just be your chest hair and not anything else!  26.

dialogues.speaker: DANTE, (0.S)
dialogues.text: What about when you flushed a tampon and ruined the entire Easter weekend!

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: You cheat on me I'll light that chest hair on fire, I swear to God! Joy starts to cry. Ronnie turns her attention to Joy, tri to lighten the mood.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I still can’t believe you didn’t call me. Why didn’t you call me?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I just--it was all happening so fast and I--I had to get the kids and then...I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Well listen. You’re the closest thing to a sister that I’1l ever have. Lord knows I prayed for one but God gave me four brothers. (looks up to the heavens disapprovingly) Four mamalukes. (then) But you’re my family too, Joy. And we’re gonna get through this.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: When I was a kid, I always knew about the women in my dad’s life. I could hear my parents arguing about it all the time. And they would call the house. My mom would cry in the bathroom. But I remember this one day, one of’em came to the door and I was right there in the dining room and she told my mom she'd been with my dad. But she felt bad cause she didn’t know he was married and she thought my mom deserved to know. And when she was leaving, she looked at my mom kinda confused and she said “I’m surprised he runs around. You look like a wonderful lady.” And my mom...she just went upstairs and went to bed and she never really came out. I’m 6 years old, making dinner for my brother.  27.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: You did the right thing, Joy. You're doin’ the right thing. Ronnie lights a cigarette. Joy pulls herself together. Wi her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I gotta get a job. Since Tony lost his last job, we’re already way in the hole.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Well you know, there’s the job fair at church on Sunday. Joy nods, lost.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One foot in front of the other, Joy. EXT. JOY’S HOUSE. EVENING. POV through Joy’s living room window--Joy sits across fro her three kids, who sit on the sofa with their hands in t laps like three peas in a pod. Joy gives them the news. INT. JOY AND TONY'S HOUSE. NIGHTTIME. Joy climbs into bed. She lays down facing Tony’s side of bed. She stares at it, then she quickly flips over facing other direction. Bobby enters.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Mommy? Joy turns to see all three kids standing there.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Alright, come on in. Just for tonight, okay? All the kids run in.

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everybody in. Good.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Mommy, will we still get to go to the Mets games?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yep. We’1l still do everything we did before. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Daddy won't sleep here, but you'll still see him and do fun things with him and I promise nothing else is gonna change. We’re still going to be one big happy family. The kids settle to go to sleep. LATER. The kids are all asleep. Joy is WIDE AWAKE, staring at th ceiling. She shifts. She shifts again. Unsettled, Joy reaches into her night-stand drawer and grabs a SONY WALK and switches it on. It’s Richard Marx,”Right Here Waiting “Oceans apart, day after day, and I slowly go insane...") INT. JOY’S KITCHEN. MORNING. Joy is on the phone with Toots.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: Terrible. This is just terrible. I've been a wreck all day thinking about this. I’m just devastated. I've been light-headed and dizzy. I had to take three Advil, Joy.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, mom. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: Tony! I just can’t believe this. Tony is gone, that’s it. It’s over.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: Joy, are you sure? Are you sure you want to do this?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: What? Mom. I saw him. I saw.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: But why divorce? Why so extreme?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Mom, you're divorced.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: Not till after you were grown. And I would have never left your father. He left me. I would have stuck it out. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As much of a ga-ga-gatz (dickhead) as your father was, at least he kept a roof over our heads.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to spend my life sitting behind the door until morning.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: What else is there? Joy, don’t try to do this on your own. You don’t know what you’re getting yourself into. INT. CHURCH HALL. A sign on the door says “JOB FAIR TODAY.” Joy enters with kids, they are dressed having come from Church. Joy stands at the doorway and surveys the room: There are bunch of TABLES set up. A few UNEMPLOYED PEOPLE talk to different company reps, some sit and read brochures, some wander around with a LOST LOOK. She notices the priest, FATHER BENEDETTI, talking to a company rep at the EASTERN AIRLINES table.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER BENEDETTI
dialogues.text: They are legal citizens but many of them don’t speak English. They are very hard working. I have several families. Standing with the priest is a small group of Dominican people. They look desperate.

dialogues.speaker: COMPANY REP
dialogues.text: If I hear of anything I will let you know.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER BENEDETTI
dialogues.text: Thank you so much. The priest turns to Joy as he escorts the group to anothe table. He PATS JOY ON THE SHOULDER as he escorts the grou another table. Joy walks up to the Eastern Airlines table

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hi. I’ve flown your airline before. INT. EASTERN AIRLINES. Joy stands behind the ticket counter. First day jitters.  30.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I can help you over here. Off Joy’s hopeful look, we begin Joy without Tony MONTAGE -wears her EASTERN AIRLINES uniform, forces a big smile, greets Christie and Bobby as they get off the bus. -picks up Jackie from Toots’ house. -cooks dinner while helping kids with homework. in the basement pulling clothes out of the dryer. -at supermarket in work uniform with three kids. -at her kitchen table, balancing her checkbook. -a MAN hands her a DINER APRON. -now in a DINER UNIFORM, carrying plates, making her way through a busy diner. -in DINER UNIFORM at Toots’s house, loading sleeping chil into the car. -in basement making more elaborate wreaths. She’s doing i -mops the diner alone at night. -Joy finishes mopping the basement, sits down tired. -sleeps on the couch while her kids watch TV -sleeps in break room at Eastern Airlines. -at McDonald's with the kids, sees a dad tickling his daughter in line as she laughs. Then glances over to a co in love. -at Toots’ house late at night-- Joy, in her Airlines uniform, loads her sleeping children into her car. -Joy stands in her FLOODED BASEMENT next to a BUSTED WATE HEATER. A workman gives her an estimate as wreaths and al her supplies lie under the water and float by. -Three kids in Joy's bed. Joy tries to get in, there’s no much room. She makes the most of a corner, falling asleep INT. JOY’S BATHROOM. The kids sit in the tub. Joy pours hot water from a pot i the tub. She tries to keep their spirits up.  31.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: You know, this is how people did it in the old days. They didn’t have automatic hot water. How’s that, is that warmer?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I’m still cold mommy. INT. JOY’S KITCHEN. CONTINUOUS. Joy tests the water in one of the pots and burns her fing

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Ow! Shit. INT. JOY'S HOUSE. EVENING. Joy, looking very worn down in her DINER uniform, tidies the living room. She looks through the front window to ch on the kids, who are sitting on the curb with their suitcases. She looks at the clock. It’s 5 PM. EXT. CURB. JOY’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. Disappointed, she comes outside. The kids look at her, worried.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: He'll be here. He probably just got caught up at work and he’s on his way. Sometimes on Fridays there's a lot of traffic and its much harder to get here.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE
dialogues.text: He’s a deadbeat.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Christie!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE
dialogues.text: I heard at school that a deadbeat is a dad that doesn’t show up and he doesn’t always show up.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: He does. He just--Your father is your dad. He’s a part of us, we are a part of him. He’s our family and we're all connected and we need to love each other, okay?  32. Suddenly, Tony’s car motors up, TOM JONES music blasting. is relieved.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Daddy! ! Tony gets out of the car, beaming. He looks FRESH AND RES He’s dressed well, full of energy. Like he’s just come ba from vacation-the OPPOSITE of how Joy looks. He’s carryin plastic bag. Joy adjusts her skirt and smooths her hair.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hey guys!!!

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Daddy!!/Hi Daddy/Let’s go!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I know. I’m sorry. I went somewhere and was getting you guys something and it took longer than I thought.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: What?/What is it?! Out of a bag, Tony takes out a bunch of souvenirs--hats, shirts, flags, that all read RIVERHEAD RACETRACKS. The ki are excited. Joy silently reacts to this.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Great stuff! Wow! Okay guys, seatbelts! The kids open the door and pile into the car. Tony and Jo are left alone.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Okay, so um... Sunday morning?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sunday. (then) How ya doin?  33.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Good. Awkward pause. Joy goes to the car.

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gosh! What am I gonna do without you guys?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You’re gonna work.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yes, yes I am. Come here. She kisses each of them as Tony gets into the drivers sea

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: I love you/Bye mommy. Joy closes the door. She watches the car pull away with h THREE KIDS FACES pressed up against the window waving at Christie looks concerned. Joy stands there too long. A heaviness comes over her. Sh turns, starts to adjust her work uniform. INT. DINER. Different shots of Joy running her ass off. Busy night. INT. DINER. MIDNIGHT. Joy, TIRED, takes a bin full of glasses and plates throug the swinging doors into the kitchen. She grabs a MOP out the corner and comes back out to behind the counter area starts to mop. As she’s mopping, the DIRTY WATER is POOLI on the floor. Joy grimaces at it. She goes to put the mop in the WRINGER and the winch/wrin jams. She jerks it to try to un-jam it, but it’s stuck. S uses her bare hands and tries to wring the mop out, but something unidentified and disgusting comes off on her ha Frustrated, she tries the wringer again. It won’t budge. jerks it again hard, the winch BREAKS. Joy slips, takes a HARD, VIOLENT FALL onto the floor. Joy lays on the dirty floor without moving. This is her l After a moment, she sits up, rubs her hip with her hand, pain. She grabs the mop and angrily THROWS IT across the floor.  34. She leans up against the cabinet and looks around the roo There are still lots of tables left to be bussed. The clo reads 12:30. She slowly and carefully pulls herself up, grabs a bus-bin, and goes back to work. INT. DINER. 1 AM. Joy puts on her coat and heads to the door. She stops, remembering something. She heads back into where she fell The mop still lies there. She picks the mop up, sticks it the bucket, and rolls it back into the kitchen by the mop handle, into it’s designated corner. She stares at the mop. She stares at it for a very long t INT. RUDY’S AUTOBODY SHOP. DAY. Joy sits alone at a large workbench in a corner, SKETCHIN SOMETHING, intensely focused. In the background, the men about their business. ANGLE ON: her hand grabbing a wooden BROOM HANDLE out of hardware store bag. She lays the BROOM HANDLE on the tabl ANGLE ON: a TAPE MEASURE measures the length and width of broom handle. ANGLE ON: a HUGE SPOOL of ROPE comes out out of the bag a begins to make LOOPS with it. Two of the goombahs and Rudy work on getting a car up on lift. DOMINIC addresses Joy from across the room.

dialogues.speaker: DOMINIC
dialogues.text: Hey Joy. So what you working on?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: A project.

dialogues.speaker: DOMINIC
dialogues.text: Yeah, what kind of project?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Just this idea I have.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: My daughter the inventor. She’s like--who’s that broad that makes all those crafts, that tv broad?

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: Martha Stewart.  35.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: (mocking) Yeah, she’s Martha Stewart. Ever since she’s a kid I’m tripping over these gadgets she likes to make. Goombah number two, ANTHONY, amuses himself--

dialogues.speaker: ANTHONY
dialogues.text: I wish she could invent me a sandwich. I’m starving.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: From the looks of it, Anthony, you don’t need another sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: Ohhhh!!! Joy remains focused.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: The men eat their lunch, talking and glancing over at Joy who’s still at it. She tugs on a wire and pulls it again. FRUSTRATED, SHE TAKES THE WHOLE THING APART. They chuckle We see VARIOUS SHOTS of JOY BUSY AT WORK, looping rope, rigging PVC piping to the broomstick, taking it apart AGA More shots of Joy RE-DOING the same steps--measuring and sawing more piping, re-fitting the piping onto the broomhandle, carefully finessing the wiring. Determined. She stretches he back and legs, the clock reads 4:30 pm. A few customers come in and out. Joy stares at the project. She grabs DUCT TAPE out of her hardware store bag and takes her tape measure out again. The guys start shutting the place down, leaving for the d Joy looks at her finished project as it’s laid out on the table--a HAND-MADE PROTOTYPE OF A MOP. She’s pleased. Rudy walks up and looks at the prototype. It’s not pretty It’s rigged with duct tape, wires everywhere and piping.

dialogues.speaker: HAS A LEVER ATTACHED THAT PUSHES TWO METAL RODS DOWN THAT
dialogues.text: SQUEEZE THE MOP. He’s confused. He grabs her sketch of it glances at it. He looks from the sketch to the prototype.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: The drawing’s not great but it’s all in my head. The lever pushes the rollers down and wrings it out.  36. Joy demonstrates proudly. She pushes the LEVER down. The BREAKS APART. A bunch of pieces fall to the floor. Rudy i not impressed. As he walks out--

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Alright. Make sure to lock up. Joy goes to THROW the mop, but catches herself. Frustrate she throws the pieces in a bag and gives up. EXT. JOY’S HOUSE. EVENING. On the way into the house, Joy drops the bag of mop parts the trash. INT. JOY’S HOUSE. Joy gives her kids a bath, dunks a washcloth in the water

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Okay, come here Jackie. Come here. Jackie offers up her BACK for Joy to wash. Joy WRINGS OUT WASHCLOTH. While wringing it out, she watches her WRIST. dunks the washcloth and DOES THE MOTION AGAIN. And again. thinks. The kids are quiet. Watching her. Jackie, with her back t Joy, waits to be washed.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Mom what are you doing? Joy dunks the washcloth one more time. She wrings it. It’ quiet as the kids stare at her. EXT. JOY'S HOUSE. Joy fishes the discarded mop parts out of the trash. INT. JOY’S BASEMENT. CONTINUOUS. Joy has the PROTOTYPE on the table and pours all of her p out of a bag onto the table that was once covered in wrea She quickly takes parts off of the mop. She goes to work at it again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. JOY’S BASEMENT. Joy is asleep on the table. The clock reads 6 a.m. A voic wakes her up.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE
dialogues.text: Mommy? Joy jolts up to see Christie standing there in her pajama It’s daytime. Joy forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hi. INT. RONNIE’S HOUSE. DAY. Kids play in the backyard. Ronnie stares at Joy through t smoke from her Virginia Slim.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I think it’s genius.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: It’s a ‘self-wringing’ mop.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I gotta try this. Ronnie gets up. Joy hands her the mop. Ronnie dunks it in water, twists the handle and wrings it out while never ha to put her cigarette down. It’s easy.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my god. Look at this! How did you do this?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I wrote it down, and then I just started putting it together.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I’ve never seen anything like this. Other people are gonna want one of these.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: You think?  38.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I need one. My hands look like bird claws from all the cleaning chemicals. My nails don’t fit into the gloves.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: The wreaths always helped with bills and stuff and now that i’m not doin’em... I don’t know, you really like it? You think people might buy something like this? Like I could sell’em?

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I think you could sell the shit out of ‘em. INT. JOY'S DINING ROOM. NIGHT. Rudy, Viv, Ronnie, Dante sit at the table. The kids sit a separate kids table. Joy cleans. Rudy is holding court.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: So Joey Gallo gets whacked.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Dad. The kids.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Sorry. Joey Gallo gets gunned down--

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Dad. Joy puts an espresso down in front of Rudy.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: --at that restaurant on Mulberry and Elizabeth street. They shot him in between seafood courses.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: That’s almost 20 years ago now.

dialogues.speaker: DANTE
dialogues.text: I remember that.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Umberto’s Clam House--Matty the Horse’s restaurant. Matty was there the night Joey was killed, so the FBI got to thinking maybe he might have had something to do with it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So Matty and I had done some business on the up and up over the years. Little stuff. I get a call. It's Matty. He’s breathing heavy, I could barely understand him on the phone. Tells me he needs to go on the lamb from the government. Joy puts a piece of pie in front of Rudy. She dutifully scoops ice cream onto his plate. He digs in. RUDY (CONT’D) He’s gotta get outta town. He says “Rudy. You gotta do me a favor... Joy joins in, she’s heard this story before. RUDY (CONT’D) JOY You’re the only one I can “You're the only one I can trust.” trust.”

dialogues.speaker: RUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I met him at a Dunkin’ Donuts on Queens blvd. I drove him and Benny Cohen all the way to Florida in my Buick Regal.

dialogues.speaker: DANTE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: True story. As I live and breathe.

dialogues.speaker: VIV
dialogues.text: Were you scared?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I‘m aman. In a time like that your natural instincts take over. Viv is impressed. Mission accomplished.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: So let me get this straight. You drove a murderer all the way to Florida with his murdering friend so that the cops couldn’t put them in jail for murdering people.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Somethin’ to be proud of, Dad. Joy sits down at the table with a Yellow Pages and flips through. Rudy is annoyed at her for pulling focus.  40.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: What are you doin? We’re in the middle of dinner.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Can I show you something? INT. JOY’S BASEMENT. MOMENTS LATER. Joy, Ronnie, Rudy and Viv Ronnie are looking at the mop.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I still don’t get it. I mean I don’t mop, so...

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: It wrings by itself. You don’t have to break your back to bend down, and stick your hands in dirty water. It’s genius. You heard it here first. She’s tuned into something. Every housewife in America is gonna want one of these mops.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Alright, take it easy. Rudy looks at the mop.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This looks different from the one you showed me. Rudy holds the mop awkwardly. Viv sits and unwraps a cand Joy flips through the Yellow Pages.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yeah I fixed it. This one’s right.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: What we should do is we make a bunch of’em. And we can do a show! A presentation, in front of like store owners and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yeah. This takes a long time to do each one by hand. We need to find a way to make more.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Whoa whoa whoa. Put the Yellow pages down, it’s embarrassing. (cocky) What you need is to get a mold made.  41.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: A mold. They'll take your main part there and make a mold of it, so then you can get a hundred or a thousand of these things whenever you want. And quick. That’s what the pros do.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: That’s what I want to do.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: They're expensive.

dialogues.speaker: VIV
dialogues.text: Rudy you know people. Isn’t there somebody you could call?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: (showing off) Well sure, yeah. I got a guy out in LA. Evan Reynolds. Runs Avalon Industries. Makes all my parts. I’1l make a call. Joy is excited and very grateful.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Great! Thanks, Dad!

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: But you two need to figure out how to move these things. That should be your focus.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Ok.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I mean it! I’m puttin’ myself on the line here. It’s gonna be up to you guys to move these things. Joy and Ronnie smile at each other. INT. FACTORY. A HUGE SIX BY SIX SLAB OF STEEL IS POURED AND STAMPED. Jo mop is being born.  42. INT. JOY'S LIVING ROOM. HUGE boxes are stacked up taking up most of the living ro Joy opens one, grabs a mop head, starts putting pieces together. She ASSEMBLES HER FIRST OFFICIAL MOP. EXT. A&P. EARLY MORNING. Joy and Ronnie stand in the parking lot in front of the store. Ronnie holds the bucket and Joy holds one of the m Ronnie nods at a woman walking toward them.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Here she comes. Our first customer.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hi. The woman keeps walking. They watch her in silence a mome

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Wait. We need a plan. Why don’t I wrangle’em, I lure ‘em in, and then you hit’em with the pitch. A CUSTOMER passes by. Ronnie goes out towards her.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Ma’am. I noticed you have very dry, scaly hands. The woman walks away, visibly angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joy is demo’ing the mop for someone.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: It has a locking device here on the handle and this part twists, and when you twist the handle, see the pin slides under, the loops tighten, and they wring themselves out. The woman starts walking away.

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And... good bye. Joy and Ronnie look defeated.  43. EXT. DRUG STORE -NOON. Ronnie greeting another woman.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Hi. Does your husband pee all over the floor? The woman keeps walking. Joy looks at Ronnie.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? That’s what I use my mop for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she demos, Joy is falling more in love with her invent

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I have to say this sliding mechanism is my favorite part. See I put a little tension rod for additional pressure, This design is very good.

dialogues.speaker: DIFFERENT PEOPLE PASSING JOY AND RONNIE
dialogues.text: SHAKING THEIR HEADS AT THEM “No.” “No.” “No.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronnie and Joy put a bunch of mops in trunk and close it. They sit in the car.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I still think we just need a better location. Joy nods, but she’s clearly feeling defeated. INT. TOOTS’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. Toots, on the PHONE, is glued to the Home Shopping Networ The kids watch, bored. Joy enters, tired, but forces a sm

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hi! The kids RUSH to her.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Mommy/I missed you/Can we go home?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hey mom--—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toots shushes Joy, talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Okay. It’s a Visa--this is so exciting- As Toots reads off her credit card number into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE
dialogues.text: Mom. She won't turn it off. ANGLE ON: T.V. A female host’s voice talks over an image two porcelain horses.

dialogues.speaker: T.V. HOST
dialogues.text: And we're running out of time for these porcelain horses, mother and fawn. Only FIVE minutes left for the amazing price of 19.99 and we're gonna throw in this ladies embroidered cosmetic bag. Chrystal, tell us about this bag!

dialogues.speaker: CHRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Well its Le Sportsac, need I say more?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (to kids) Okay. Kids, get your stuff. Run up and get your shoes on, let’s go. The run off. Joy is upset with Toots. When she hangs up-

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: How did it go today?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Um...We’re figuring it out. Have you been watching this all day?

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: They sell anything you can think of, Joy. It’s incredible. I’m gonna have these horses on the mantel by Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I can’t find my other shoe!

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: It’s in my room, honey!

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Mom you can’t just plant the kids in front of the tv all day.  45.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: Well you were gone a long time, Joy.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I told you 3:00. I asked you if it was gonna be too much.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: I just didn’t think you’d really be gone that long, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I’m hungry.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (to Toots) Did they eat?

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: I offered, Joy, but there’s not a lot in my cupboards. I’m alone.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Alright guys, come on. Lets go get some dinner. INT. K-MART PARKING LOT. NEW DAY. Ronnie and Joy stand with a bunch of mops. They gear up.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Okay. New day. Fresh start. Great spot.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: At least this place has a little more traffic. Ronnie, seeing two women approach, hurries around to the front and pretends to be a customer. She loudly overacts.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Wow, this looks interesting. I’m in such a hurry today, what’s this? The woman gives Ronnie a weird look and keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: Joy pulls the mop out of the bucket and accidentally splatters water on someone.  46.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oops. Oh. It’s just so light. But still durable. I’m not trying to brag. But this is-- bye.

dialogues.speaker: DIFFERENT PEOPLE PASSING THEM AND SHAKIN
dialogues.text: THEIR HEADS AT THEM AS THE DAY PASSES. “No.” “No.” “No.”

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: Joy and Ronnie are EXHAUSTED. They sit on the CURB, defea Ronnie calls out to people as they walk by, who IGNORE he

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Hey. Ponytail! Ponytail and blue shirt. Hey! Crew cut! Crew cut and flip-flops. Glasses and bangs. You snooze you lose!

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Stop. Joy, laughing, puts her hand over Ronnie’s mouth to stop but it’s too late--They are delirious. A woman passes the pushing her kids in a cart. She wears VERY TIGHT HOT PINK STRETCH PANTS--too tight. They’re not very flattering.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Stretch pants. Pink tights!

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Ronnie--

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (whips around, pissed) What did you say? Joy and Ronnie sober up.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Nothing. I just said stretch pants. I was trying to get your attention. So now that we’re here--

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I heard you making fun of me.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: What? No.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Just because I didn’t stop to talk to you, you insult me?  The woman The woman 47.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I wasn’t insulting you, I swear to God. You had pink stretch pants on so I called out ‘Pink stretch pants.’

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Do you have permission to be out here? Does the store manager know? I think he should know you're out here making fun of his customers. heads into the store. Joy rushes to her.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: NO!!! Please. Don’t. Please. My friend has a big mouth.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: All I said was stretch pants!

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: We've been out here a little too long and it was totally out of line that my friend said that. We're just delirious, that’s all it is.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: It’s not nice.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. There is NOTHING wrong with your pants. Please. Please don’t tell the manager. stares at them. Then, she breaks down.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You caught me on a bad day for this, you know. I’ve had a very hard day.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (immediately empathetic) Oh no! What happened?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (emotional) My son flushed his underwear down the toilet this morning and backed up the sewage in my house.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh my god.  48.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. When I woke up to get out of bed, I stepped in toilet water. Then as I was walking to shut the toilet off, I stepped on a floater.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: It’s poop. She stepped on a piece of poop.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: That’s horrible! I’m so sorry. I feel terrible that we added to it. (then) How old is your son?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: He’s five. Joy BECOMES COMPLETELY HERSELF, now, just relating to the woman, conversationally.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh, I have a five year old! He stuck a raisin up his nose a couple of weeks ago and I had to take him to the EMERGENCY ROOM and it cost me 300 dollars to have them take it out with the tweezers. I’ve been in those days when it’s just one disaster after another. (Hands her a mop) Here. Have this.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You don’t have to give it to me for free. (looking at the mop) How does this work?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (conversational, casual) Oh. It’s really easy. You know how when you normally mop, you dunk and then wring, but it never quite picks everything up and it makes a mess?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah I always end up getting down on the floor-  49.

dialogues.speaker: JOY WOMAN
dialogues.text: With paper towels... With paper towels...

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To clean up the mess from the mopping after I mop.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Exactly. This mop does all in one. With this mop I don’t get the dirty water slushing all around, I don’t have to put my hands in there, and it’s easier on my back cause I’m not bent over struggling with that wringer. And the head comes off so I can throw it in the wash or bleach it. I love it.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Wow. You made this? This thing’s unbelievable. A FEW PASSERSBY notice the STRETCH PANTS WOMAN ENGAGING W JOY AND their interest is peaked. One WOMAN stops to look

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (turns to her) Um, it’s a mop.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You selling it? Joy, caught off guard, turns to see ANOTHER WOMAN standin the other side of her.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Hi. Yeah it’s for sale. Ronnie steps back in.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: She made this, you know. She designed it herself.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Well you know I got tired of--I don’t know how you feel about cleaning, but I HATE mopping. I mean, I don’t like cleaning in general..who does, I guess.  50. The women nod in agreement. As another person walks up, J begins to demo the mop again.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: Joy and Ronnie stand in shock. They don’t even know what hit them.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: One left. Sure enough, there is only one mop left. Joy and Ronnie l at each other. They hug each other, CRAZY EXCITED.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: What happened

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: They don’t wanna know about the mechanics. They just wanna talk. It was crazy, you were on a roll, it was like a feeding frenzy. Joy can’t contain herself. She looks at Ronnie, BEAMING. Ronnie turns so Joy can see their reflection in the store window.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at us - Big shots! (Looks closer) I’m gonna need new Reeboks. (Another long look) We look like shit. INT. TOOTS’S HOUSE. Joy enters. Same scene as before. HSN is on. Kids are bor

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hill!

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Hey mom/hi

dialogues.speaker: HSN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...this 5 piece Barbacue Utensil set. It’s the fork, the spatula, the tongs and two shakers... Toots comes quickly down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: This isn’t what it seems. I just turned it on. Christie shoots Joy a look. Joy shakes her head.  51.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (trying to distract Joy) Anyway, how did it go?!

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Good. We sold 27 mops.

dialogues.speaker: CHRYSTAL, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: How many?! (back to audience) My friends, we just passed the 95,000 mark of these, we only have 5,000 left. And from the looks of it, we are going to run out in just minutes. This has been a record- breaking Home Improvement weekend... Joy notices that on the screen, it says NUMBER SOLD, it i already gone up BY 200 in about fifteen seconds. Joy star at the counter as the number keeps quickly rising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joy and Ronnie after another long day. Ronnie gives chang one last BUYER as Joy puts the one unsold mop in the car.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh no! Are you all out? A YOUNG WOMAN, 20s, blonde, pretty, has exited the store.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: No, actually we have one more.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Oh good. I'll take it. I had to run in and get cash from my boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (joking) Hmmm. Where can I get a boyfriend who hands me cash? Just then, TONY appears. The woman addresses him.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: This is it, honey, see? Joy is SHOCKED. Tony sees Joy. He goes WHITE.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Ohhhh...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: This thing is cool.  52.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hey Joy.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Ronnie.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Tony.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: You guys know each other?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: This is my...ex-wife. The young woman looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Really. She stares at Joy. Joy, self-conscious, smooths her hair.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Joy this is--Michelle.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hi. Michelle sizes Joy up. Joy holds the mop in front of her try to cover a COFFEE STAIN on her shirt. Michelle looks right at it.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What are you guys doin out here?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (humiliated) We're selling these. I made’em and we're just out here selling them. To people. It’s been a good day. Awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Where are the kids?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: At my mom’s. More awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Right. Okay. Mops, huh?  53.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: People really like’em.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (sincere) That’s great. Anyway, um, well I guess I'll see you next weekend for the kids.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yep. Okay, bye! Michelle stands there awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE
dialogues.text: Can I still get a mop?

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: It’s the least you can do. EXT. TOOTS’S HOUSE. Joy sits in her car, pulling herself together. She’s been crying. INT. JOY’S HOUSE. NIGHT. Joy strains to carry a full laundry basket to the couch. feet are KILLING HER. She sits to rub them. Turns on the Channel 29 comes on. Two hosts demonstrating a DUSTBUSTER She watches them with growing interest. INT. AIRPORT. Joy, in uniform, is on a pay-phone.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hi. I wanted to know how people go about submitting a...product for your show? EXT. KMART. Joy talks to Ronnie.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: You submit a sample and they review it and they decide if they think it’s good enough to go on the air.  54.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Well, what are we doin out here then? INT. POST OFFICE. DAY. Joy tinkers with MOP SUBMISSION materials. She and Ronnie reluctantly hand the mop over the counter. They watch nervously as the POSTAL CLERK flings it into a bin behind her. INT. JOY’S HOUSE. BACKYARD. DAY. Jackie is arguing with Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (to Bobby) You're stupid! Jackie hauls off and HITS BOBBY with the bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joy pulls a sweatshirt over her head and runs down the st as the PHONE IS RINGING, yelling out to the kids.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: What happened?! Joy runs into the kitchen and answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (0.S)
dialogues.text: She took my bat!

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Hi, Joy? This is Valerie from HSN.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hi Valerie. (to kids) Guys! Jackie! Shh!!!

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Is this a bad time?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: No, no, no, it’s great.  55.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Hi. First off, we want to thank you for your submission.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Joy, while on the phone, goes to the door and watches as Bobby yanks on the bat, but Jackie won’t let go.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Give it!!

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (cupping phone, to kids) Jackie give Bobby the bat. Joy makes a signal to her kids. They keep fighting.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: We get hundreds of thousands of submissions a year and we carefully review every single one.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: After careful review of yours--

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Jackie! (cupping phone) Give Bobby the bat.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: --we decided to give it a shot. Joy doesn’t make the shift.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: We're going to debut your mop on the 19th. Joy is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? Joy recovers from her shock enough to reply.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m here. Thank you. That’s good news.  Jackie is SCREAMING. Bobby holds one end of the bat and 56. DRAGS JACKIE around the backyard, as she keeps her grip o the bat.

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bobby! !

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is an okay time? I can call you back a little later.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: No, no, no. It’s fine. I’m sorry. Can you hold on one second? Joy goes outside, stretches the phone cord out the door. cups the phone and speaks URGENTLY in a YELLING WHISPER.

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get over here. Everyone. Listen. We are all a family. Do you know what that means? We are a team. We have to LOVE each other and help each other. We are all we have. This is it. Let’s hug. Lets not fight. I am on the phone so please just give me this!! I’m begging you! Love each other! The kids stop, stare at her, thrown by her passionate ple

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (back into phone) Sorry Valerie.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: We are gonna need a few things from you. We need a logo. We need a name for the mop. And we need 7,000 units.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Seven--thousand. In the background, Jackie hands Bobby the bat. He gives h the ball.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Yes. Electronic retailing happens fast and in a lot of volume, so we have to be prepared.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: That’s no problem. No problem. Okay. Oh. Okay.  57.

dialogues.speaker: VALERIE
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you. Joy hangs up. The kids are looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They liked it. They like the mop. The kids stare at her. INT. RUDY’S AUTOBODY SHOP. Joy stands across from Rudy and Viv.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Okay. Evan Reynolds can handle the 7,000 and he’1l have’em done in a week.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: But you gotta pay him 15 grand. Joy’s mouth drops.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: You’re lucky, trust me. He’s cutting you a deal ‘cause of me.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I know. I just don’t know how I’m gonna come up with that kind of money.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Well don’t look at me, I got you this far. I can’t hold your hand the whole way. I got my own business to run. You’re gonna have to get creative. Joy thinks.  58. INT. BANK. Joy sits nervously at a desk. The KIDS play behind her. T BANK MANAGER points at her PAPERWORK on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: BANK MANAGER
dialogues.text: Just sign here. And here. And here. We see the document LOAN AMOUNT is for 15,000 dollars. Jo signs two of the dotted lines hesitantly. At the last lin she stops. The bank manager senses her anxiety. BANK MANAGER (CONT’D) Alot of people use their homes as collateral for loans. For emergencies, you know, you need some cash. It’s not like you’re signing you’re house away. As long as you make the payments, your house stays yours. Joy takes a very LONG BEAT. She looks at the loan documen looks at her kids, looks at the BANK MANAGER. Then, Joy s on the last line. INT. KINKO'S COPIES. CONTINUOUS. Joy and Ronnie manage their five kids while busy at work, drawing, printing, gluing and copying.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: What about... (dramatically) Mop-tastic? Joy isn’t sure.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
