dialogues.text: Ten days. John thinks.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CALCAGNY
dialogues.text: Well, there’s only one option that can get the molds back in time to fulfill the HSN order.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Okay. What?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CALCAGNY
dialogues.text: We file an emergency request for a temporary restraining order. It’s not the kind of restraining order you hear about in domestic cases. This TRO is filed when there is an emergency need for something to happen immediately. For example, to prevent the demolition of a building, or to stop a sale of a company from happening. It’s specifically used for urgent and timely cases like yours.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Okay.  117.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CALCAGNY
dialogues.text: We file, saying we need to be heard tomorrow. The court will grant us a hearing within two days, then we go in and present our evidence. It’s not a formal trial, the whole case is heard in one day. But we do go in front of the judge. And he summons the Avalon guys in. We have to prove that not only are we in the right, but that if the court doesn’t step in now, grant us an injunction, and get the molds back immediately, it will be a massive loss. One you can never recover from.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: That’s us. That’s me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CALCAGNY
dialogues.text: Yeah but hold on. John looks distressed.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CALCAGNY
dialogues.text: The courts don’t like these cases.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CALCAGNY
dialogues.text: Judges want cases to go forward in a traditional fashion, to play themselves out. They stand by the system that’s in place, no risk or appeal. They feel a TRO is askin for special treatment. They feel if the system is good enough for everybody else, it should be good enough for you. TRO cases are virtually impossible to win. This is a one shot deal. A Hail Mary pass. If you win, you have a chance of victory going forward. If you lose....it’s over. Joy has a determined look in her eyes. JOHN CALCAGNY (CONT’D) Not to mention we're going up against the mob.  118. INT. RONNIE’S HOUSE.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I say you take it to ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: DANTE
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about? Matty the Horse doesn’t fool around.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I say to hell with ‘em. I say we take the mop, the molds, the warehouse, the trip to California and shove it the whole thing up their fat Italian asses, Joy.

dialogues.speaker: DANTE
dialogues.text: What?! Do you hear yourselves?? They buy judges. That trucking company got that big judgment. I read in the paper They found that judge living in Hawaii. Living there. Sipping pina coladas! Ronnie, you’re stayin’ home.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: The hell I am. I wanna see these goons sweat.

dialogues.speaker: DANTE
dialogues.text: Oh they’re gonna sweat alright. While they’re digging your grave.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Tony says they don’t come after wives or kids.

dialogues.speaker: DANTE
dialogues.text: Okay. I’1l1 tell everybody that when I’m giving your eulogy. Dante storms out, then turns around.

dialogues.speaker: DANTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The two of you are FUCKED. This whole thing is fucked!! He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Thanks for gettin’ him tuned up. I love when he gets like this.  119. INT. WAREHOUSE. DAY. Joy and Ronnie sit in front of a mountain of paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: All of June is in red binders and July is in blue. August is orange. My anal retentiveness is really coming in handy.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: It’s a gift. They hear a muffled BOOM outside. EXT. WAREHOUSE. DAY. Joy and Ronnie walk out of the warehouse. At first they s the dumpster on FIRE. They see a BLACK CADILLAC speeding away. They look at each other. Suddenly, there is another boom as the DUMPSTER behind them goes up in FLAMES. They at each other, sober. INT. JOY’S HOUSE. NIGHTTIME. Joy sits nervously in her kitchen going over paperwork. SUDDENLY, there is a banging at the front door. She is FRIGHTENED. She grabs a knife and goes to the door. She g the courage to look through the peephole. She breathes a sigh of relief and opens the door. It’s Rudy.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Can I come in? Joy rolls her eyes and gestures for him to come in. Rudy on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. The kids are asleep?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: It’s 11 o’clock, dad.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Right. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: What’s goin’ on?  120.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Look, I know things have been a little tense. Joy just looks at him. RUDY (CONT’D) Tomorrow morning. This TRO thing? You can’t do it, okay? You gotta call it off.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (disbelief) I’m not cancelling the hearing, dad.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Come on! This has gone way too far. People are gonna think I can’t control my own family. Its embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yeah, that sounds tough, dad. Beat. Rudy sighs, deeply.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I’m 69 years old, Joy. And I know you don’t think that much of me. You think I’m a bad father, but I remember some good times. Times with your mom even. You think I'ma failed businessman, but you kids never starved and were never forgotten on your birthdays. Maybe it ain’t much. But, well-I can’t change the past. I can’t. Tomorrow they’re gonna call me up there. They're gonna make me their witness. And they’re gonna ask me about all of it: the mop, the paperwork, you. What am I gonna do? In front of everyone, you're going to force me to make a choice. So I’m asking you: please don’t make me make this choice.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: You don’t understand, dad. If I were you, there would be no choice.  INT. Joy who and INT. Joy and John sit in one of the rows. Dante (wearing sunglasses as a disguise), and Toots. quiet. Rudy and Viv sit on the other side. JOY'S BEDROOM. COURTHOUSE. eye contact with Joy. 121. lies in bed, WIDE AWAKE, anxious. She looks at her kids, are sleeping peacefully. She puts her WALK-MAN on again turns it on. Behind them is Ronnie, It’s Rudy cannot make Suddenly, the doors open and an entourage of EXPENSIVE SU AND BRIEFCASES enters. Their entrance breaks the silence and the sound of their shoes echoes the room. They pass her, if in slow motion, none acknowledging her except the last one, Matty the Horse, who stares Joy down as he walks pas her and sits down, still staring at her. The men sit. The entire room sits in very awkward silence Finally, the BAILIFF enters. They all rise as the JUDGE enters.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: All rise, the honorable Judge David Brady. humorless. Joy is intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Alright, have a seat. They all sit.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're hear today because plaintiff Joy Mangano is moving for emergency release of an affirmative injunction forcing defendant Matthew Aianello to relinquish certain manufacturing molding equipment related to the production of a mop. Counselor, you may make your argument. John stands up. Joy is extremely nervous.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CALCAGNY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Joy Mangano is the inventor of the Miracle Mop. She created the product on her own. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The judge speaks,  122.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN CALCAGNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Early on, she sought the assistance of her father in production of certain molds that are fundamental in the manufacturing process. Unbeknownst to her, her father made a deal with Mr. Aianello to produce the molds. As production increased, Mr. Aianello made unreasonable cost demands that made production and distribution of said mop impossible. This effort at conversion by the Defendant has been catastrophic for Ms. Mangano’s business, for herself, and for her children. We are asking the court to grant Ms. Mangano possession of her manufacturing molds in order for her to filla very large order made by the Home Shopping Network. If the court does not grant this, tens of thousands of orders will go un-filled, and Ms. Mangano’s business and reputation will be destroyed. We have sufficient evidence to support our claim. Various shots of John presenting evidence, engaging with judge. A shot of her first SKETCH of the mop. A photo of her and Ronnie at KMART. Shot of a proud Ronni Joy hands the bailiff a video tape. He pops it into a VCR It’s the video of Joy on HSN.

dialogues.speaker: CHRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Well good evening here on HSN I’m your host Chrystal Gaines and we are gonna end this Thursday with our incredible Deal of the Day... Joy looks nervous as we...

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: Matty’s lawyer is now standing. Joy is sitting. MATTY’S LAWYER Well, having seen the video, I'll take two. There is laughter from the courtroom. Even the Judge laug Joy looks worried.  123. MATTY’S LAWYER (CONT’D) Unfortunately the only thing this video proves is that this woman can sell mops. And none of the other evidence is binding with relation to legal ownership of the mop. Your honor, our client owns the patent for this mop. Its all here in plain black and white. He presents the PATENT to the judge. MATTY’S LAWYER (CONT’D) The law is clear here. We are asking the court to acknowledge this for what it is - a family dispute. A petty feud. We understand that, unfortunately, Miss Mangano’s business is failing. No one’s sadder about this than my client. (turns to Joy) I know you’re divorced and are raising three children and it must be very hard. We sympathize with your financial struggles, but we also think we all know what this is- (turns back to the Judge) It is nothing more than a money grab. We are simply asking the court to uphold our legally binding contract. Thank you, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (looking at patent) Counselor, who is Rudy Martorella? MATTY’S LAWYER The plaintiff's father your honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Mr. Martorella, please come take the stand. Rudy stands up and makes his way to the stand.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Do you promise to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you God?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: So, Mr. Martorella, according to this document you transferred ownership of the patent to Mr. Aianello. Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Yes, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: How did you acquire the patent in the first place?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: I filed it at the office.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: No, why did you file it? Are you the inventor of the mop? Rudy is visibly uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Uh, well, for a while I was kickin’ it around, you know, it’s not the only thing I thought about inventing. I thought of an ashtray on a stand that sits by the couch--

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Did you invent the Miracle Mop? Yes or no. Rudy looks over in JOY’'S DIRECTION, but not at her. He l in Matty’s direction. Long pause. He nervously fidgets.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Yes. The room reacts. Joy is let down. Viv gets up, takes her purse, and leaves the room, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Thank you, lets take a recess so I can look over some of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOY, TOOTS, RONNIE, and DANTE exit the court room. JOY is devastated.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: (to JOY) I can’t believe this. Stugatz!  125.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: When that man dies I will step on his dead body. Matty approaches.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: MATTY
dialogues.text: Excuse me. May I have a word with you, Joy?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Uh. Yeah, sure. Let me find my attorney. Joy looks around for John.

dialogues.speaker: MATTY
dialogues.text: This’ll only take a minute. You don’t need him.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Okay (to her group) Guys? Toots and Dante walk away. RONNIE doesn’t. Matty looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I’m part of the company. Matty shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MATTY
dialogues.text: Joy, my attorneys tell me you're gonna end up with nothing. They say it’s a slam dunk. I feel terrible about this. This is your family. And you're arguing with each other. Family is not supposed to be like this. I want this to be over. I want to make it right.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I’m glad to hear you say that.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: MATTY
dialogues.text: I wanna settle this between us, right here and now.  126.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MATTY
dialogues.text: I would like to offer you twenty thousand dollars. You withdraw your claim to ownership of the patent. You walk home with somethin’ in your pocket. And nobody’s hung out to dry.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Twenty thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: MATTY
dialogues.text: (sympathetically) Yeah. Its starting to get embarrassing in there, you’re own father testifying against you. That can’t be easy for you personally. I admire you though. You came here, you gave it your best shot.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I don’t think I’1l take the deal.

dialogues.speaker: MATTY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: No, thank you. What you're doing isn’t right. And your offer is insulting.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I agree with that.

dialogues.speaker: MATTY
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa. No one’s trying to insult you. We’re having a business discussion here.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I don’t wanna do your kind of business.

dialogues.speaker: MATTY
dialogues.text: I’m talking about 20 grand here. It’s that or zero when I go back in there and win this case.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Well it’s not over yet. Matty’s demeanor changes. We see the mob boss in him.  127.

dialogues.speaker: MATTY
dialogues.text: I was tryin to be nice. For your dad. (close to her face) But you’re just like him. A fuckin’ mooch with big plans and no pocketbook. I’m gonna bury you in there. And I'll see you in a couple of weeks when you come beggin me for money. He walks off. Joy and Ronnie are very scared.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Okay. So now we know. We got that squared away.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind?! Joy and Ronnie are back with Toots and Dante.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Mom, I can’t just sit here and let this go. I’ve tried and I can’t go down like this.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: You are gonna go down. You’re going down! You should have taken the money. Cause now you’re gonna end up with nothing. And have thought about your mother? I come all the way down here riddled with the shingles and you pull this on me?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Mom, this has nothing to do with you.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: Of course it has to do with me. Who do you think’s gonna take care of kids when these people are done with you??

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Am I supposed to think that would be you?? Since when has that ever been you, mom?

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: Shame on you for talking to your mother this way. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your father destroyed me. And he’s gonna destroy you. And you want me to sit here and watch it happen. The courtroom DOORS open. People begin filing back in.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: No one’s asking you to stay. In fact, I don’t want you to. Unless, for once in your life you can find a way to be a mother and root for me. What’s it gonna be Mom? You staying or going? Toots stares at Joy for a long beat. She grabs her purse the bench and heads into the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: The man’s never even picked up a mop in his life. This comment hangs in the air. John appears.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Where were you? I’ve been looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I had to go for a walk. Clear my head.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: We need a plan, do you have a plan?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I think so. Joy is panicked. The bailiff flags them into the courtroo

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Come on. Let’s go. They enter the courtroom. INT. COURTROOM. MOMENTS LATER. Back in session. Rudy is at the witness stand. John stand up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So, you invented the mop? Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Wow. That must be exciting to see something like this take off for you.

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Yes, yes it is.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: So, why was your daughter on TV, not you? The inventor?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: She handles the creative part. I do the business part of the deal.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Who handles the inventing part? Matty’s attorney stands up. MATTY’S LAWYER Objection. He’s asking the same question over and over.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Upheld. (to JOHN) Do you have any new questions? One that hasn’t been answered already? John is searching. He sees Joy. She signals to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: One second, your Honor. John comes to Joy. They whisper.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Tell him you want me to talk.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Joy, you don’t want this to turn into a quarrel here. She is dead stern.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Please. Do it. John turns to the Judge.  130.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Your Honor, Ms. Mangano has something she’d like to say.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: By all means. She grabs the mop off of the display table.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Your Honor. Will you please ask Rudy to mop the floor? MATTY’S LAWYER Objection-- Joy looks at the judge.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: He invented it, I just want to see him use it. Ask him to come down and mop the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Overruled. (turns to Rudy) Mr. Martorella. The judge signals for Rudy to come down to the floor. Rud reluctantly gets up, embarrassed, and walks down to Joy. hands him the mop and bucket.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: There’s no water in here, but you know what to do. Rudy, shaking his head, trying to act cool, dunks the mop the bucket, fumbles with the sliding mechanism a bit, pus instead of pulling, barely pulling it off. It’s not a CLE RESULT. Rudy looks at the judge, throwing his hands up as to say “See, I did it.”

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry. One more thing. Can you ask my dad to take off the mop head and put it back on? Rudy tries to take the mop head off. He can’t figure out where the button is. He tries a few different unsuccessfu ways.

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I? Joy takes the mop and detaches the mop head in a millisec She then puts it back on and works the wringer. She turns the judge.  131.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Mr. Martorella, you may sit down. Rudy goes back to his chair. Joy goes back to her table a turns to the judge, matter of fact.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: This mop isn’t the first thing I’ve invented. Its just the first thing anyone has ever bought. Its really amazing seeing people buy this thing. It makes me feel something I’ve never felt before. Proud. I’m sure these guys have that same feeling. Because they have the ‘paperwork’ right there that says they own, conceived, and created my mop. They were the ones slipping on the floor of Sam’s Diner at midnight. They were the ones that figured out you need to put a pin in the mop or it won’t work right. Or that if you slip your finger over the housing when you’re assembling it, you’ll get your skin pinched every time. Right guys? They have to know about the skin pinching. Because they have the paperwork. It says this mop is theirs. You could tell by the way they talk about it. Its personal for them. It’s their blood, sweat, and tears. I don’t have that paperwork. It was taken out from underneath me. While I was busy trying to make this thing happen, I was betrayed. And I guess honesty and integrity don’t have a receipt. There’s no patent for hard work. (beat) My whole life people have been telling me you can’t do this and you shouldn’t try that and you don’t deserve this. It’s been like noise in my head for a very long time. I just wanna walk away from all the noise. To you, it’s a mop. To me, it’s a way out. All I’m asking for, your honor, is what has always been mine. And the paperwork to prove it. Thank you. The judge nods. He is quiet for a long time. He calls the bailiff over and whispers to him. The bailiff walks out o the room, then comes back with more paperwork. Joy watche every move. The judge finally speaks.  132.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Where are these mop molds being held? MATTY’S LAWYER In California at our Avalon facility.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Okay. Counsel, contact the facility and have them load the manufacturing molds, all parts dealing with the manufacturing of these mops to be loaded onto trucks and shipped here immediately. MATTY’S LAWYER Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: And take them to Ms. Mangano’s warehouse. MATTY’S LAWYER Your honor?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I’ll further order a sheriff's escort to accompany the trucks to make sure that nothing mysteriously happens to the trucks along the way. I am not only granting the TRO. I hereby grant all legal rights to the Miracle Mop and it’s proceeds to Ms. Mangano.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Oh my God. MATTY’S LAWYER We have the patent--

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I'm nullifying the patent. It is to be re-filed in the name of Joy Mangano. There is an audible reaction from the room. He turns to J

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good luck to you. He hits the gavel. Ronnie bursts into tears. Everyone on Joy's side erupts in celebration. Ronnie, runs to Joy, th hug each other. They all hug. Joy hugs Toots, who is completely dumbfounded. She hugs Ronnie very tightly.  133. As she hugs Ronnie, Joy looks over Ronnie’s shoulder, acr the room to Rudy. Rudy sits isolated, no longer part of the family, no long respected by the mob. Shamed. He looks pathetic. Joy watches him. A hint of sympathy comes across her face. Joy's group excitedly starts to head out the door. Last i line, Joy stops where Rudy is sitting. A beat. Then...

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: We gonna see you for dinner on Sunday?

dialogues.speaker: RUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah that’d be good. INT. JOY’S OFFICES. CHYRON: 1 YR LATER. Joy is walking through what are now STATE-OF-THE-ART OFFI She is made-over, a new and improved version of herself. Confident, polished, elegant. Ronnie comes up to her, wea a business suit. Ronnie talks to her as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Joy, Dante’s on his way with the kids for pizza night.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Great. They pass by the secretary’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: JOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom, pizza in a half hour. REVEAL Toots, who is on the phone. She acknowledges Joy b stays focused.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: Thursday she’s in meetings all day but that Friday after lunch there's an opening. Joy and Ronnie still walking, they head up stairs.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Also, we need to remind the warehouse of the new back-order.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: And the head of sales wants a meeting tomorrow.  134.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Tomorrow is no good.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Well, you talk to him. Ronnie peels off. Joy opens an office door that reads HEA SALES. TONY is inside working.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hey-

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hey, I can’t meet tomorrow, Bobby’s got the science fair.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Oh that’s right.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: How’s Monday though?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Monday’s good.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Okay. The kids are almost here. Meet us in the green room in 20 minutes for pizza?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: (smiling) Yeah. Joy smiles, exits his office. She walks to a door that ha decorative grapevine wreath hanging on it. She enters. On wall is a WOMAN’S DAY MAGAZINE COVER that has been framed with JOY AND HER KIDS on the cover. “Mother of Invention” Joy opens the closet, takes her blazer off, and hangs her blazer up. The blazer slides off and falls to the floor. hangs it again. It slides off again. Joy holds the hanger stares at it, slides her fingers along the corners of the hanger, and we go off on her, wheels turning...a new invention is brewing!

dialogues.speaker: CHYRON
dialogues.text: In the next few years the Miracle Mop sold over 10 millio units. It’s sales were only outdone by Joy’s next invention: The Huggable Hanger. Today Joy's products have grossed over a half billion in sales.  135. If you asked her today, she would say her proudest achievement is her children.  136.
